title: Suspicious Encoded PowerShell Command Execution
description: Multiple detections of encoded PowerShell usage within the last 12 hours. Encoded commands are commonly used by attackers to obfuscate malicious scripts and evade detection. These detections exclude known benign scripts (gc_worker, ACL, Nessus), increasing confidence that the activity is not routine admin scripting.

mitre.description: Adversaries may abuse PowerShell commands and scripts for execution of malicious payloads, evasion, or downloading further stagers.

log_lines: 2025-12-04 19:29:14.657677+00:00,SL_Encoded PowerShell Command Detection,SL_Encoded PowerShell Command Detection,High,"Detects use of PowerShell with -enc/-encodedcommand, excluding known benign scripts (gc_worker, ACL, Nessus).",ASI Scheduled Alerts

2025-12-04 18:29:17.017697+00:00,SL_Encoded PowerShell Command Detection,SL_Encoded PowerShell Command Detection,High,"Detects use of PowerShell with -enc/-encodedcommand, excluding known benign scripts (gc_worker, ACL, Nessus).",ASI Scheduled Alerts

2025-12-04 17:29:15.888668+00:00,SL_Encoded PowerShell Command Detection,SL_Encoded PowerShell Command Detection,High,"Detects use of PowerShell with -enc/-encodedcommand, excluding known benign scripts (gc_worker, ACL, Nessus).",ASI Scheduled Alerts
notes: Correlate process start events and command lines for decoded command details. Review associated user accounts and endpoints for lateral movement or privilege escalation.

title: Suspicious Network Beaconing from CLI Utilities on Linux
description: Multiple alerts for suspicious network beaconing using command-line utilities (curl, wget, dhpcd, etc.), indicative of possible command-and-control (C2) activity, on Linux systems. Alerts are tuned for low false positives and prioritize non-standard, high-frequency, or port-diverse outbound connections not related to known update services.

mitre.description: Adversaries may communicate using web protocols via tools like curl/wget for C2 or data exfiltration.

log_lines: 2025-12-04 18:40:28.638622+00:00,"SL[LINUX] Suspicious Network Beaconing from CLI Utilities (curl, wget, dhpcd, etc.)","SL[LINUX] Suspicious Network Beaconing from CLI Utilities (curl, wget, dhpcd, etc.)",High,"Detects potential command-and-control (C2) activity originating from known command-line tools such as curl, wget, dhpcd, and custom binaries. The rule calculates a behavior score based on connection count and port usage diversity. Legitimate update services and known benign calls are excluded via pattern matching.

2025-12-04 17:40:26.793445+00:00,"SL[LINUX] Suspicious Network Beaconing from CLI Utilities (curl, wget, dhpcd, etc.)","SL[LINUX] Suspicious Network Beaconing from CLI Utilities (curl, wget, dhpcd, etc.)",High,"Detects potential command-and-control (C2) activity originating from known command-line tools such as curl, wget, dhpcd, and custom binaries. The rule calculates a behavior score based on connection count and port usage diversity. Legitimate update services and known benign calls are excluded via pattern matching.
notes: Investigate process queuing, destination IPs/domains, and any download activity. Review users/process owners for compromise.

title: Suspicious Execution of Obfuscated or Masqueraded Linux Binaries by Root
description: Detection of potentially malicious binaries executed from typical system directories (/bin, /tmp, etc.) by root user, exhibiting masquerading or obfuscation tactics (random filenames, deleted after exec, or abnormal file operations). This is typical of post-exploitation behavior, such as EDR evasion or lateral movement tools.

mitre.description: Masquerading involves actors running code from locations or with names that look legitimate to avoid detection.

log_lines: 2025-12-04 19:04:01.338605+00:00,SL_Suspicious Execution of Obfuscated or Masqueraded Linux Binaries by Root,SL_Suspicious Execution of Obfuscated or Masqueraded Linux Binaries by Root,High,"Detects execution of suspicious or potentially malicious binaries from common Linux execution directories (/bin, /usr/bin, /lib, /usr/lib, /tmp, /var/tmp) initiated by the root user. This behavior is indicative of post-exploitation activity involving masquerading techniques, use of randomly named binaries, dropped artifacts (e.g., libudev.so.6, dhpcd), or abuse of common utilities such as mv, chmod, and scp in non-standard contexts.

2025-12-04 18:04:06.394233+00:00,SL_Suspicious Execution of Obfuscated or Masqueraded Linux Binaries by Root,SL_Suspicious Execution of Obfuscated or Masqueraded Linux Binaries by Root,High,"Detects execution of suspicious or potentially malicious binaries from common Linux execution directories (/bin, /usr/bin, /lib, /usr/lib, /tmp, /var/tmp) initiated by the root user. This behavior is indicative of post-exploitation activity involving masquerading techniques, use of randomly named binaries, dropped artifacts (e.g., libudev.so.6, dhpcd), or abuse of common utilities such as mv, chmod, and scp in non-standard contexts.
notes: Correlate with persistence events, privilege escalation attempts, and possible lateral movements. Review timeline of root user actions and filesystem changes.

title: Brute Force and Excessive Failed Logon Attempts
description: There are numerous alerts indicating repeated failed logon attempts from the same remote IP to Azure VMs or hosts, consistent with brute force activity. Student/test/lab events may be noise, but frequency and distribution indicate real threat potential.

mitre.description: Adversaries may use brute force methods such as repeated logon attempts to gain unauthorized access.

log_lines: 2025-12-04 19:33:26.523204+00:00,SEWALT Alert Rule (Brute Force Attempt Detection),SEWALT Alert Rule (Brute Force Attempt Detection),Medium,Discovers when the same remote IP address has failed to log in to the same local host 10 times or more within the last 5 hours.,ASI Scheduled Alerts

2025-12-04 18:48:11.004477+00:00,SL_Brute Force External Network Login Attempts - GeoIP Enriched,SL_Brute Force External Network Login Attempts - GeoIP Enriched,Medium,Detects potential brute-force login attempts from external sources based on repeated failed network logons. Enriched with geo-location and known bad network tagging. Mapped to MITRE ATT&CK T1110 (Brute Force).,ASI Scheduled Alerts
notes: Enrich with source IPs and destination hosts. Review if any of the attempts succeeded, and check for correlated privilege escalation or lateral movement activity.

title: Impossible Travel/Unusual Geographical Sign-in Patterns
description: Multiple alerts for users authenticating from geographically distant locations within short time periods, indicating either use of VPN/proxies, account compromise, or credential theft.

mitre.description: Adversaries use stolen credentials to access resources. Impossible travel often signals credentials in use by an attacker from another location.

log_lines: 2025-12-04 19:21:18.630330+00:00,AnalyticsRule_JB_ImpossibleTravelAlert,AnalyticsRule_JB_ImpossibleTravelAlert,Medium,"Flags user sign-ins from locations over 15 km apart within 15 minutes, indicating potential account compromise. Query runs every 15 minutes.",ASI Scheduled Alerts

2025-12-04 18:40:42.350488+00:00,-dereckAlert Rule (Potential Impossible Travel),-dereckAlert Rule (Potential Impossible Travel),Medium,"Design a Sentinel Scheduled Query Rule within Log Analytics that will discover when a user logs in to more than a certain number of locations within a given time period; for example, trigger if a user logs into 2 different geographic regions within a 7 day time period. (ensure the appropriate logs show up before creating the alert rule)",ASI Scheduled Alerts

2025-12-04 18:29:42.831207+00:00,Potential Impossible Travel - seb,Potential Impossible Travel - seb,Medium,"Sometimes corporations have policies against working outside of designated geographic regions, account sharing (this should be standard), or use of non-corporate VPNs. The following scenario will be used to detect unusual logon behavior by creating an incident if a users login patterns are too erratic. “Too erratic” can be defined as logging in from multiple geographic regions within a given time period.
2025-12-04 18:38:28.246359+00:00,Opal - Potential Impossible Travel,Opal - Potential Impossible Travel,High,,ASI Scheduled Alerts
notes: Investigate frequency and user context. Cross-reference with MFA failures, new devices, or administrator roles.

title: PowerShell Web Requests Indicating Possible Remote Payload Download
description: Alerts triggered on execution of PowerShell commands making web requests (often via Invoke-WebRequest). This behavior is indicative of an attacker downloading payloads or tools during post-exploitation, persistence establishment, or further lateral movement.

mitre.description: Adversaries may transfer tools or payloads onto victim systems by making web requests from a command shell, often using PowerShell.

log_lines: 2025-12-04 17:51:55.932735+00:00,AshJ - Create Alert Rule (PowerShell Suspicious Web Request),AshJ - Create Alert Rule (PowerShell Suspicious Web Request),Medium,"Sometimes when a bad actor has access to a system, they will attempt to download malicious payloads or tools directly from the internet to expand their control or establish persistence. This is often achieved using legitimate system utilities like PowerShell to blend in with normal activity. By leveraging commands such as Invoke-WebRequest, they can download files or scripts from an external server and immediately execute them, bypassing traditional defenses or detection mechanisms. This tactic is a hallmark of post-exploitation activity, enabling them to deploy malware, exfiltrate data, or establish communication channels with a command-and-control (C2) server. Detecting this behavior is critical to identifying and disrupting an ongoing attack.
2025-12-04 16:57:40.816029+00:00,PowerShell Invoke-WebRequest Detected,PowerShell Invoke-WebRequest Detected,High,,ASI Scheduled Alerts
notes: Obtain URLs/domains involved and file hashes of downloaded content. Review for execution of newly downloaded files or scripts.

title: Internet Facing System Alert
description: Multiple high-severity alerts indicating systems are exposed to the internet. These represent an increased attack surface for exploitation and should be reviewed for accidental exposure or misconfigured access control.

mitre.description: Public-facing systems are a frequent target for exploitation, brute force, or reconnaissance attempts.

log_lines: 2025-12-04 19:06:08.285399+00:00,is Internet Facing Alert,is Internet Facing Alert,High,Check system that are internet facing,MDATP
2025-12-04 18:46:48.373168+00:00,is Internet Facing Alert,is Internet Facing Alert,High,Check system that are internet facing,MDATP
notes: Determine intended/authorized exposure. Review external firewall rules and recent public scans or exploits.

title: Suspicious Network Beaconing from Linux CLI Utilities (Potential C2 Activity)
description: High-fidelity detection of network beaconing originating from Linux CLI tools (curl, wget, dhpcd, etc.) was triggered. The activity was scored based on unusual connection count and diverse port usage patterns typical for command-and-control (C2) channels. Pattern matching excluded known legitimate traffic, increasing confidence in malicious intent.

mitre.description: Application Layer Protocol: Web Protocols—use of legitimate network utilities to establish outbound C2 channels

notes: This is a low-false-positive rule. Immediate incident response and network pivoting recommended.

title: Encoded PowerShell Command Detected
description: Execution of PowerShell using the -enc or -encodedcommand flags, which is indicative of TTPs for obfuscation often seen in malware or post-exploitation scripts. Known benign scripts were excluded according to the detection logic.

mitre.description: Obfuscated Files or Information: Command Obfuscation—adversaries encode commands to evade detection.

log_lines: 2025-12-04 19:29:14.657677+00:00,SL_Encoded PowerShell Command Detection,SL_Encoded PowerShell Command Detection,High,Detects use of PowerShell with -enc/-encodedcommand, excluding known benign scripts (gc_worker, ACL, Nessus).
notes: Validate process ancestry and command content. Encoded PowerShell is a strong sign of malicious activity.

title: Suspicious Execution of Obfuscated or Masqueraded Linux Binaries by Root
description: Detection of suspicious or potentially malicious binaries executed from standard Linux directories by the root user. Criteria includes masquerading techniques, random file names, deleted binaries post execution, or suspicious file operations—strong post-exploitation signal.

mitre.description: Masquerading: Masquerade Task or Service—adversaries rename executables or execute from legitimate locations to evade detection.

notes: Review for lateral movement or persistence mechanisms; confirm if binaries are truly unauthorized.

mitre.description: Valid Accounts—adversaries leverage compromised credentials for unauthorized access from disparate geography

title: Suspicious Network Beaconing Indicative of Command and Control (C2) Activity via CLI Utilities
description: Behavioral analytics detected potential C2 communication from a Linux system via CLI utilities such as curl, wget, or dhcpd. The activity is flagged by a high-signal, low-noise rule designed to catch suspicious connections from command-line tools outside usual update/service patterns. This is typically associated with malware or post-exploitation tooling attempting outbound comms.

mitre.description: Application Layer Protocol: Web Protocols — Adversaries use standard web protocols for C2 and data exfiltration

log_lines: 2025-12-04 19:40:28.738772+00:00,"SL[LINUX] Suspicious Network Beaconing from CLI Utilities (curl, wget, dhcpd, etc.)","SL[LINUX] Suspicious Network Beaconing from CLI Utilities (curl, wget, dhcpd, etc.)",High,Detects potential command-and-control (C2) activity originating from known command-line tools such as curl, wget, dhpcd, and custom binaries...
indicators_of_compromise: CLI utilities: curl, wget, dhcpd (process context)
notes: The alert is tuned for low false positives; post-exploitation or active malware likely. Immediate response required.

title: Encoded PowerShell Command Execution Detected
description: Execution of PowerShell with -enc or -encodedcommand flag detected, excluding known benign scripts. This TTP is frequently used by attackers to obfuscate their intentions and bypass inspection tools, and is commonly part of post-exploitation, malware delivery, or lateral movement.

mitre.description: Command and Scripting Interpreter: PowerShell — Execution of encoded/obfuscated commands

log_lines: 2025-12-04 19:29:14.657677+00:00,SL_Encoded PowerShell Command Detection,SL_Encoded PowerShell Command Detection,High,Detects use of PowerShell with -enc/-encodedcommand, excluding known benign scripts (gc_worker, ACL, Nessus).
notes: This usually indicates active attacker activity or automation using obfuscated PowerShell.

title: Suspicious Execution of Obfuscated or Masqueraded Linux Binaries by Root
description: High-confidence detection of a root-initiated process in a Linux environment executing binaries from common system directories (e.g., /bin, /tmp) that exhibit masquerading, random/filedropped naming, or are deleted post-execution. This pattern is consistent with privilege escalation or post-exploitation, often following initial compromise.

mitre.description: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location — Adversaries may masquerade binaries post-exploitation to hide actions.

log_lines: 2025-12-04 19:04:01.338605+00:00,SL_Suspicious Execution of Obfuscated or Masqueraded Linux Binaries by Root,SL_Suspicious Execution of Obfuscated or Masqueraded Linux Binaries by Root,High,Detects execution of suspicious or potentially malicious binaries from common Linux execution directories (/bin, /usr/bin, /lib, /usr/lib, /tmp, /var/tmp) initiated by the root user...
indicators_of_compromise: Process context: root running unknown/random binaries
notes: Detects classic post-exploitation. Immediate investigation and host isolation recommended.

mitre.description: Valid Accounts — Adversaries may leverage compromised accounts and attempt access from locations inconsistent with user behavior.

title: Nessus or similar scanner-based file and network enumeration using PowerShell
description: Multiple instances of PowerShell are executed with encoded or obfuscated command lines performing wide recursive file discovery and sensitive file collection (site-packages, PKG-INFO, METADATA, various directories), including using custom PowerShell scripts and writing results to the TEMP directory. Log sequence shows enumeration indicative of vulnerability scanning and host discovery (Nessus or similar) on host vm-final-lab-gi.

mitre.description: Adversaries may enumerate files and directories on a system to identify data of interest and potential targets for subsequent actions.

log_lines: 2025-12-04 20:17:27.102861+00:00,vm-final-lab-gi,gilbert,ProcessCreated,vm-final-lab-gi,powershell.exe,"powershell  -NoProfile -Command \"& {$j = sajb {$ErrorActionPreference = 'SilentlyContinue'; ... (recursive directory enumeration and custom powershell script)\"  ","powershell.exe -Version 5.1 -s -NoLogo -NoProfile"

2025-12-04 20:17:23.942513+00:00,vm-final-lab-gi,gilbert,ProcessCreated,vm-final-lab-gi,powershell.exe,"cmd.exe /c C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowershell\v1.0\powershell -NoProfile -Command \"& {$j = sajb ... ;$r = wjb $j -Timeout 1620; rcjb $j;}\" > C:\Windows\TEMP\nessus_KCS1HW8N.TMP & ren C:\Windows\TEMP\nessus_KCS1HW8N.TMP nessus_KCS1HW8N.TXT","powershell  -NoProfile -Command ..."

2025-12-04 20:17:23.780539+00:00,vm-final-lab-gi,gilbert,ProcessCreated,vm-final-lab-gi,cmd.exe,wmiprvse.exe -secured -Embedding,"cmd.exe /c C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowershell\v1.0\powershell -NoProfile -Command ... > C:\Windows\TEMP\nessus_KCS1HW8N.TMP & ren ..."
notes: Activity pattern fits Nessus or other compliance/vuln scanner; extensive file enumeration with custom scripts and writing to TEMP, likely sensitive data collection.

title: Network Connection Enumeration with netstat.exe Windows utility from PowerShell
description: Execution of netstat.exe via PowerShell and conhost on host vm-final-lab-gi, output redirected to temporary file for later retrieval (matched Nessus scan patterns).

mitre.description: Adversaries may attempt to get a list of network connections to and from the compromised system to identify potential C2 channels, active sessions, or other applications in use.

log_lines: 2025-12-04 20:06:37.722754+00:00,vm-final-lab-gi,gilbert,ProcessCreated,vm-final-lab-gi,NETSTAT.EXE,"cmd.exe /c \" C:\Windows\System32\tasklist.exe /FO csv /svc > C:\Windows\TEMP\nessus_task_listTOXZC9HX.TMP & ren C:\Windows\TEMP\nessus_task_listTOXZC9HX.TMP nessus_task_listTOXZC9HX.TXT\"","netstat.exe  -ano  "
notes: netstat enumeration as part of a scan or credential collection workflow; file redirected to temp for later collection—correlates with known scanner behaviors.

title: Extensive Execution of net.exe and auditpol.exe for Account/Policy Enumeration
description: Unusually high frequency of net.exe (via net1.exe and auditpol.exe) process launches with 'accounts' argument, scattered across multiple hosts (main1-srvr, og-sccorp-01, windows-target-1, vm-final-lab-ke, zero-day-markd), parents are often PowerShell scripts or cmd.exe, and output redirection is often present. The volume and distribution exceed regular admin activity, indicating scripting or automated enumeration.

mitre.technique: Account Discovery (T1087) and Permission Groups Discovery (T1069)
mitre.description: Adversaries enumerate user accounts and security groups to inform attack progression or privilege escalation paths.

log_lines: ... (multiple log lines from ~18:46:47 to 20:17:31 on various hosts, ex. ... ,net.exe,"powershell.exe -ExecutionPolicy AllSigned -NoProfile -NonInteractive -Command \"& {if ($ExecutionContext.SessionState.LanguageMode -eq 'FullLanguage') {$OutputEncoding = [Console]::OutputEncoding =[System.Text.Encoding]::UTF8}else {chcp 65001}; & ...' }\"","net.exe accounts"
notes: CONTEXT: The pattern and frequency are not normal for hands-on admin work; likely driven by scanner, script, or attacker mass enumeration logic.

title: Widespread log scraping and information collection using tasklist.exe and systeminfo-like commands via PowerShell
description: Detectable across hosts in process chains: tasklist.exe, systeminfo.exe/related, netsh, and others executed from PowerShell or cmd.exe, frequently dumping output to temporary files (Nessus or similar pattern).

mitre.description: Adversaries may enumerate system info to collect OS, service, and running process data.

log_lines: 2025-12-04 20:06:39.746737+00:00,vm-final-lab-gi,gilbert,ProcessCreated,vm-final-lab-gi,tasklist.exe,"cmd.exe /c " C:\Windows\System32\tasklist.exe /FO csv /svc > C:\Windows\TEMP\nessus_task_listTOXZC9HX.TMP & ren C:\Windows\TEMP\nessus_task_listTOXZC9HX.TMP nessus_task_listTOXZC9HX.TXT"",tasklist.exe  /FO csv /svc
notes: Output files named for classic vulnerability scan context (temp/nessus_*.TXT/TMP); cross-correlation likely to pick up further discovery steps.

title: Linux scripting enumeration: aggressive process and OS enumeration consistent with automated scanning
description: Numerous Linux-targeted commands (ps, ls, uname, cat /etc/os-release, printenv) executed in quick succession from scripted parents (sh/dash/batch). Context shows enumeration of processes, OS version info, wireless extensions, CPU/mem, systemd-unit activity — consistent with audit/discovery runs. Many commands show scan-style pivots.

mitre.technique: System Information Discovery (T1082), Process Discovery (T1057), System Owner/User Discovery (T1033)
mitre.description: Scripted enumeration of Linux system and user info to document asset configuration, privilege, and posture.

title: Suspicious Use of PowerShell with Encoded Commands
description: Multiple high-severity detections for encoded PowerShell commands (with -enc/-encodedcommand) were observed. Encoded commands are commonly used by attackers to obfuscate malicious activity and evade detection. These detections exclude patterns attributed to known benign scripts.

mitre.description: Attackers encode or obfuscate PowerShell commands to avoid detection by security solutions.

log_lines: 2025-12-04 20:29:13.927620+00:00,SL_Encoded PowerShell Command Detection,SL_Encoded PowerShell Command Detection,High,"Detects use of PowerShell with -enc/-encodedcommand, excluding known benign scripts (gc_worker, ACL, Nessus).",ASI Scheduled Alerts

2025-12-04 19:29:14.657677+00:00,SL_Encoded PowerShell Command Detection,SL_Encoded PowerShell Command Detection,High,"Detects use of PowerShell with -enc/-encodedcommand, excluding known benign scripts (gc_worker, ACL, Nessus).",ASI Scheduled Alerts

2025-12-04 18:29:17.017697+00:00,SL_Encoded PowerShell Command Detection,SL_Encoded PowerShell Command Detection,High,"Detects use of PowerShell with -enc/-encodedcommand, excluding known benign scripts (gc_worker, ACL, Nessus).",ASI Scheduled Alerts
notes: Investigate all associated host activity, process chains, and potential lateral movement. Highly correlated with post-exploitation.

title: Repeated Detection: Powershell Hercules-soc
description: High-severity detection of suspicious PowerShell activity labeled "Powershell Hercules-soc" across multiple systems. No benign explanation in log context. This alert pattern is often associated with credential theft, lateral movement, or execution of unauthorized code.

mitre.description: Adversary is using PowerShell to execute malicious scripts or commands.

log_lines: 2025-12-04 20:46:19.577728+00:00,Powershell Hercules-soc,Powershell Hercules-soc,High,Powershell,MDATP
2025-12-04 20:46:19.556214+00:00,Powershell Hercules-soc,Powershell Hercules-soc,High,Powershell,MDATP
2025-12-04 20:46:19.551614+00:00,Powershell Hercules-soc,Powershell Hercules-soc,High,Powershell,MDATP
notes: Correlate with any user, process, or network anomalies and review host for evidence of persistence or privilege escalation.

title: Multiple PowerShell Invoke-WebRequest Detections
description: High-severity alerts for PowerShell using Invoke-WebRequest observed several times. This command is frequently abused by attackers to download additional payloads, tools, or exfiltrate data directly from a compromised host.

mitre.description: Adversary downloads files/tools from remote locations to the compromised environment.

log_lines: 2025-12-04 20:42:41.735467+00:00,PowerShell Invoke-WebRequest Detected,PowerShell Invoke-WebRequest Detected,High,,ASI Scheduled Alerts
2025-12-04 20:33:00.332088+00:00,PowerShell Invoke-WebRequest Detected,PowerShell Invoke-WebRequest Detected,High,,ASI Scheduled Alerts
notes: Investigate associated network connections and check for any downloaded files or subsequent anomalous activity.

title: Suspicious Network Beaconing from CLI Utilities (Linux)
description: High-severity alerts for command-and-control (C2) style network beaconing detected from Linux command-line utilities (curl, wget, dhpcd, etc.). Behavior score methodology suggests notable volume and/or port diversity, filtering benign update patterns.

mitre.description: Network beaconing over HTTP/HTTPS, initiated by CLI tools, a common method for attackers to contact C2 infrastructure.

log_lines: 2025-12-04 20:40:26.670284+00:00,"SL[LINUX] Suspicious Network Beaconing from CLI Utilities (curl, wget, dhpcd, etc.)","SL[LINUX] Suspicious Network Beaconing from CLI Utilities (curl, wget, dhpcd, etc.)",High,"Detects potential command-and-control (C2) activity originating from known command-line tools such as curl, wget, dhpcd, and custom binaries. The rule calculates a behavior score based on connection count and port usage diversity. Legitimate update services and known benign calls are excluded via pattern matching.",ASI Scheduled Alerts
notes: Correlate with process ancestry, outbound destinations, and potential payload delivery on affected hosts.

title: Suspicious Execution of Obfuscated or Masqueraded Linux Binaries by Root
description: High-severity detection for execution of suspicious, obfuscated, or masqueraded binaries by root from common Linux execution directories. Binaries with random names, dropped artifacts, or atypical file operations (including deletion after execution) indicate post-exploitation or persistence techniques.

mitre.description: Obfuscated or renamed binaries executed as root are a strong indicator of adversary activity following successful privilege escalation.

log_lines: 2025-12-04 20:04:03.532698+00:00,SL_Suspicious Execution of Obfuscated or Masqueraded Linux Binaries by Root,SL_Suspicious Execution of Obfuscated or Masqueraded Linux Binaries by Root,High,"Detects execution of suspicious or potentially malicious binaries from common Linux execution directories (/bin, /usr/bin, /lib, /usr/lib, /tmp, /var/tmp) initiated by the root user. This behavior is indicative of post-exploitation activity involving masquerading techniques, use of randomly named binaries, dropped artifacts (e.g., libudev.so.6, dhpcd), or abuse of common utilities such as mv, chmod, and scp in non-standard contexts.",ASI Scheduled Alerts
notes: Review file operations, ancestry, and all root activity for lateral movement or further privilege escalation.

title: Brute Force External Network Login Attempts
description: Multiple medium-severity alerts indicating potential brute-force login attempts from external sources. Triggers based on repeated failed logons, enriched with geo-location and bad network tagging. This may represent an active external attack attempting to compromise credentials.

mitre.description: Repeated login failures from external IP addresses—commonly seen during credential stuffing or password-guessing attacks.

Enriched with geo-location and known bad network tagging. Mapped to MITRE ATT&CK T1110 (Brute Force).,ASI Scheduled Alerts

Enriched with geo-location and known bad network tagging. Mapped to MITRE ATT&CK T1110 (Brute Force).,ASI Scheduled Alerts
notes: Review target accounts and source IP addresses; escalate if brute-force attempts succeeded or originated from multiple geo-locations.

title: Multiple 'Impossible Travel' and Unusual Sign-in Locations
description: Numerous alerts for logins from geographically disparate locations within short time windows (impossible travel) and successful sign-ins from countries or locations not typically associated with user patterns. May indicate compromised accounts, use of anonymizing VPNs/proxies, or policy violations.

mitre.description: Signs of credential compromise with session hijacking or account use from multiple disparate locations.

2025-12-04 20:24:50.131850+00:00,CM-Impossible Travel Rule,CM-Impossible Travel Rule,Medium,...
notes: Review user activity, source IP, MFA, and device context for impacted accounts. Possible false positives if known travel or VPN use.

title: Encoded PowerShell Command Detected
description: Multiple detections of PowerShell executed with encoded commands, which is frequently used for obfuscation and evasion. Exclusions for known benign scripts are in place, increasing the fidelity of these alerts.

mitre.description: Obfuscated Files or Information: Command Obfuscation

description: Multiple high-severity alerts for potentially malicious PowerShell execution flagged as 'Hercules-soc'. Could indicate persistent or ongoing post-exploitation activity.

mitre.description: Command and Scripting Interpreter: PowerShell

title: Suspicious Linux Network Beaconing via CLI Utilities
description: Detected suspicious network beaconing originating from standard network CLI utilities (curl, wget, dhpcd) possibly indicating command-and-control (C2) traffic.

mitre.description: Application Layer Protocol: Web Protocols

log_lines: 2025-12-04 20:40:26.670284+00:00,"SL[LINUX] Suspicious Network Beaconing from CLI Utilities (curl, wget, dhpcd, etc.)","SL[LINUX] Suspicious Network Beaconing from CLI Utilities (curl, wget, dhpcd, etc.)",High,"Detects potential command-and-control (C2) activity originating from known command-line tools such as curl, wget, dhpcd, and custom binaries. The rule calculates a behavior score based on connection count and port usage diversity. Legitimate update services and known benign calls are excluded via pattern matching.
notes: Requires enrichment with connection details (destination IPs/domains) and process lineage for confirmation of maliciousness.

title: Suspicious Linux Execution by Root: Obfuscated or Masqueraded Binaries
description: High-severity detection of potentially malicious binaries launched from common Linux execution directories by the root user. This matches patterns associated with post-exploitation (e.g., masquerading, dropped artifacts, or binaries deleted after execution).

mitre.description: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location

log_lines: 2025-12-04 20:04:03.532698+00:00,SL_Suspicious Execution of Obfuscated or Masqueraded Linux Binaries by Root,SL_Suspicious Execution of Obfuscated or Masqueraded Linux Binaries by Root,High,"Detects execution of suspicious or potentially malicious binaries from common Linux execution directories (/bin, /usr/bin, /lib, /usr/lib, /tmp, /var/tmp) initiated by the root user. This behavior is indicative of post-exploitation activity involving masquerading techniques, use of randomly named binaries, dropped artifacts (e.g., libudev.so.6, dhpcd), or abuse of common utilities such as mv, chmod, and scp in non-standard contexts."
indicators_of_compromise: Execution of uncommon binary names under /bin, /usr/bin, /lib, /tmp, /var/tmp by root
notes: Correlate with file creation/deletion and network activity from the same host.

title: Impossible Travel / Suspicious Login Patterns Detected
description: Multiple alerts (AnalyticsRule_JB_ImpossibleTravelAlert and related) reporting sign-ins from geographically impossible locations within short timeframes. This may indicate credential theft, account misuse, or VPN/proxy anomaly.

mitre.description: Valid Accounts: Domain Accounts

2025-12-04 20:48:50.464522+00:00,Touba - Impossible Travel,Touba - Impossible Travel,Medium,"Design a Sentinel Scheduled Query Rule within Log Analytics that will discover when a user logs in to more than a certain number of locations within a given time period; for example, trigger if a user logs into 2 different geographic regions within a 7 day time period. (ensure the appropriate logs show up before creating the alert rule)",ASI Scheduled Alerts
indicators_of_compromise: User accounts with sign-ins from anomalous geographic regions
notes: Correlate user login patterns, check for simultaneous sign-ins from distant regions, and review for lateral movement.

title: Bulk Resource Group Creation Across Multiple Subscriptions
description: Hundreds of resource groups were created in rapid succession within a two-hour window, all by identity 5deb2a08-7269-47d6-896b-8bc52d396466 from IP 4.153.100.221. The frequency and volume are well outside normal baseline patterns and may indicate automation or setup for further attack stages such as infrastructure for access/persistence or staging for Execution/Lateral Movement.

mitre.description: Adversaries create cloud resources and infrastructure to facilitate later stages of attack.

log_lines: 2025-12-04 20:07:41.214874+00:00,MICROSOFT.RESOURCES/SUBSCRIPTIONS/RESOURCEGROUPS/WRITE,Start,STUDENT-RG-6417DE865ADFAB25D6570931170D415DA4C35F231B6486C6E76F08AEB8558C64,5deb2a08-7269-47d6-896b-8bc52d396466,4.153.100.221,

2025-12-04 20:07:41.792991+00:00,MICROSOFT.RESOURCES/SUBSCRIPTIONS/RESOURCEGROUPS/WRITE,Success,STUDENT-RG-6417DE865ADFAB25D6570931170D415DA4C35F231B6486C6E76F08AEB8558C64,5deb2a08-7269-47d6-896b-8bc52d396466,4.153.100.221,
notes: The activity is highly abnormal in volume and frequency. Context from additional Azure RBAC logs and user activity is important to determine if this is legitimate provisioning (e.g., for a lab or exercise) or attacker preparation. Previous similar surges have been linked to fake tenant staging by threat actors.

title: Suspicious Bulk RunCommand Operations on Virtual Machines
description: Dozens of RunCommand operations were executed across multiple resource groups and targets by the same user (5deb2a08-7269-47d6-896b-8bc52d396466 and/or token), originating from IP 4.153.100.221. Several commands failed, but the wide distribution and timing suggest automation and possible staging for post-exploitation, persistence, or lateral movement.

mitre.description: Adversaries develop and deploy scripts or capabilities across cloud infrastructure to support later actions.

log_lines: 2025-12-04 20:48:49.621466+00:00,MICROSOFT.COMPUTE/VIRTUALMACHINES/RUNCOMMAND/ACTION,Failure,STUDENT-RG-65F3C8FA6052C749C6A322C192365DF9A79424E6C3DF30843B70E6CC69758648,5deb2a08-7269-47d6-896b-8bc52d396466,4.153.100.221,

2025-12-04 20:49:49.360072+00:00,MICROSOFT.COMPUTE/VIRTUALMACHINES/RUNCOMMAND/ACTION,Success,STUDENT-RG-8B069C235B64F08B1470F89D6F0E726FD0AC556EB28CE53763A7DD4823EABDE4,5deb2a08-7269-47d6-896b-8bc52d396466,4.153.100.221,
notes: Pattern, scope, and timing are consistent with malicious cloud automation (e.g., scripting, credential testing, persistence establishment, pre-positioning for C2). Review corresponding command content and investigate for lateral movement or payload staging.

title: Enumerative SAS Key Listing Events Against Storage Accounts
description: Multiple ListServiceSas operations (enumerating Shared Access Signatures) observed from identity 7d9f7bbb-a766-4124-afa5-cf9787a24b1f at 48.214.113.71 targeting various resource groups. While not always malicious in context, this access pattern may indicate key harvesting for further resource development or data exfiltration.

mitre.description: Adversaries gather and enumerate storage keys to stage for additional operations.

log_lines: 2025-12-04 20:52:45.999024+00:00,MICROSOFT.STORAGE/STORAGEACCOUNTS/LISTSERVICESAS/ACTION,Success,CYBER-RANGE-ADMIN-SOC,7d9f7bbb-a766-4124-afa5-cf9787a24b1f,48.214.113.71,
notes: If this is not linked to transparent automation (legitmate backups/CI pipelines), review corresponding storage access logs for suspicious data export or policy change events. This activity can be part of attacker key/credential scoping prior to broader compromise.

title: Suspicious Execution of Obfuscated or Masqueraded Linux Binaries by Root
description: Detected execution of suspicious or potentially malicious binaries from common Linux execution directories (e.g., /bin, /usr/bin, /lib, /usr/lib, /tmp, /var/tmp) initiated by the root user. This matches post-exploitation and masquerading behavior. Detection prioritized binaries that are deleted after execution, have random filenames, or executed in a non-standard context.

mitre.sub_technique: T1036.003 (Rename System Utilities), T1036.005 (Match Legitimate Name or Location)
mitre.description: Adversaries may masquerade malicious binaries or scripts as legitimate ones, placing them in typical execution directories or renaming to blend in, sometimes deleting after use for stealth.

log_lines: 2025-12-04 21:03:58.245979+00:00,SL_Suspicious Execution of Obfuscated or Masqueraded Linux Binaries by Root,SL_Suspicious Execution of Obfuscated or Masqueraded Linux Binaries by Root,High,"Detects execution of suspicious or potentially malicious binaries from common Linux execution directories (/bin, /usr/bin, /lib, /usr/lib, /tmp, /var/tmp) initiated by the root user. This behavior is indicative of post-exploitation activity involving masquerading techniques, use of randomly named binaries, dropped artifacts (e.g., libudev.so.6, dhpcd), or abuse of common utilities such as mv, chmod, and scp in non-standard contexts. This detection filters out known system update patterns to reduce false positives and prioritizes binaries that are deleted after execution, have random filenames, or are performing suspicious file operations.",ASI Scheduled Alerts
notes: This alert is high fidelity due to exclusion of normal update patterns and prioritization of deleted/masked binaries. Investigate accessed hosts for additional persistence or lateral movement.

title: PowerShell Hercules-soc Activity - Potential Malicious PowerShell Execution
description: Multiple high severity alerts for 'Powershell Hercules-soc' detected in quick succession. This may indicate automated or programmatic PowerShell usage associated with offensive tooling. Rapid repeated detection is suspicious and not consistent with normal administrator activity.

mitre.description: Adversaries may use PowerShell for execution of arbitrary scripts, living-off-the-land techniques, or delivering additional payloads.

2025-12-04 21:01:29.580011+00:00,Powershell Hercules-soc,Powershell Hercules-soc,High,Powershell,MDATP

title: Impossible Travel Alert - Unusual Sign-in Locations
description: Analytics flagged user sign-ins from locations over 15 km apart within 15 minutes. This is a strong indicator of potential account compromise (e.g. shared or stolen credentials, session hijacking).

mitre.description: Adversaries may gain access to valid accounts and use them to access resources, sometimes from geographically distant locations unexplained by the legitimate user.

log_lines: 2025-12-04 21:06:17.585475+00:00,AnalyticsRule_JB_ImpossibleTravelAlert,AnalyticsRule_JB_ImpossibleTravelAlert,Medium,"Flags user sign-ins from locations over 15 km apart within 15 minutes, indicating potential account compromise. Query runs every 15 minutes.",ASI Scheduled Alerts
notes: Requires immediate review of user sign-in history and confirmation with end user. Source/destination IPs, user agent, and authentication method should be reviewed.

title: Confirmed Data Exfiltration via PowerShell Script
description: Multiple endpoints (max-win11, nsds-mde-w11, vm-final-lab-gi) executed 'powershell.exe -ExecutionPolicy Bypass -File C:\programdata\exfiltratedata.ps1' and transferred data to external/cloud IPs over HTTPS. The referenced script exfiltrated data to remote destinations. The script was first staged from GitHub using Invoke-WebRequest. This is a clear case of scripted data exfiltration.

mitre.description: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel: Data is exfiltrated via command and control channels using custom script over HTTPS.

log_lines: 2025-12-04 20:49:32.473011+00:00,max-win11,20.60.133.132,443.0,powershell.exe  -ExecutionPolicy Bypass -File C:\programdata\exfiltratedata.ps1,Tcp
2025-12-04 20:49:23.336144+00:00,nsds-mde-w11,20.60.133.132,443.0,powershell.exe  -ExecutionPolicy Bypass -File C:\programdata\exfiltratedata.ps1,Tcp
2025-12-04 20:49:19.606026+00:00,max-win11,20.60.181.193,443.0,powershell.exe  -ExecutionPolicy Bypass -File C:\programdata\exfiltratedata.ps1,Tcp
2025-12-04 20:49:19.171969+00:00,vm-final-lab-gi,20.60.133.132,443.0,powershell.exe  -ExecutionPolicy Bypass -File C:\programdata\exfiltratedata.ps1,Tcp
2025-12-04 20:49:12.852074+00:00,nsds-mde-w11,20.60.181.193,443.0,powershell.exe  -ExecutionPolicy Bypass -File C:\programdata\exfiltratedata.ps1,Tcp
2025-12-04 20:49:09.655677+00:00,vm-final-lab-gi,20.60.181.193,443.0,powershell.exe  -ExecutionPolicy Bypass -File C:\programdata\exfiltratedata.ps1,Tcp
notes: This is a coordinated exfiltration event involving multiple internal hosts executing an identically named PowerShell exfiltration script staged from GitHub. Multiple sessions toward two unique external IPs over HTTPS as destinations. Host isolation and incident response are necessary.

title: Confirmed Data Exfiltration via PowerShell to Azure Blob Storage
description: Multiple hosts (max-win11, nsds-mde-w11, vm-final-lab-gi) executed PowerShell script (exfiltratedata.ps1) and established outbound connections to Azure Blob Storage endpoints (sacyberrangedanger.blob.core.windows.net, sacyberrange00.blob.core.windows.net) and IPs (20.60.133.132, 20.60.181.193) over HTTPS/443. This indicates deliberate data exfiltration using cloud storage as a drop site. Related precursor activity includes downloading the exfiltration script from raw.githubusercontent.com. The pattern is repeated across several systems and times within a 24-hour window.

mitre.description: Adversaries may exfiltrate data by uploading it to a cloud storage service over HTTPS, such as Azure Blob Storage.
